'''"Fiddlin'" John Carson''' (March 23, 1868 – December 11, 1949) was an American [[old time music|old-time]] fiddler and singer who recorded what is widely considered to be the first [[country music]] song featuring vocals and lyrics.<ref>{{Cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MYMQl9dsKJEC&q=first+country+song+carson+cabin&pg=PA12 |title = The First Generation of Country Music Stars: Biographies of 50 Artists Born Before 1940|isbn = 9780786485581|last1 = Dicaire|first1 = David|page=12|date = January 27, 2015| publisher=[[McFarland & Company]] }}</ref>

==Early life==
Carson was born near McCaysville in [[Fannin County, Georgia]]. He moved to [[Cobb County]] in his youth. His father worked as a section foreman for the [[Western and Atlantic Railroad]] Company. In his teens, Carson learned to play the fiddle, using an old Stradivari-copy violin brought from Ireland in the early 18th century.<ref name=mm17>Malone, McCulloh 1975, p. 17.</ref><ref name=mi73>Miller 1996, p. 73.</ref> In his teens, he worked as a racehorse jockey.<ref name=mm17/>

In 1894, Carson married, and a couple of years later, in 1900, he began working for the [[Exposition Cotton Mills]] in [[Atlanta]], followed by work in other cotton mills of the Atlanta area for the next twenty years, eventually being promoted to foreman.<ref name=mm17/><ref name=w65>Wolfe 2001, p. 65.</ref> In 1911, Carson's family moved to [[Cabbagetown, Atlanta|Cabbagetown, Georgia]], and he and his children began working for the Fulton Bag and Cotton Mill.<ref name=g174>Goodson 2007, p. 174.</ref> Three<ref>
Fink, Gary M. 1993 The Fulton Bag and Cotton Mills Strike of 1914–1915: Espionage, Labor Conflict, and New South Industrial Relations. Cornell University Press.</ref> years later, in 1914, the workers of the cotton mill [[1914–1915 Fulton Bag and Cotton Mills strike|went on strike]] for their right to form a [[Trade union|union]], and Carson had nothing else to do but to perform for a living in the streets of North Atlanta.<ref name=w65/> In these days, he wrote many songs, and he used to print copies and sell them in the streets for a nickel or a dime. Some of the songs he wrote dealt with real-life drama, like the murder ballad "Mary Phagan". Because the governor of Georgia, [[John Marshall Slaton]], commuted the death sentence of the wrongly convicted murderer of [[Mary Phagan]] to a life sentence, Carson, in outrage, wrote another version of "Mary Phagan" where he accused the governor of being paid a million dollars from a New York bank to change the verdict, causing him to be thrown in jail for slander.<ref name=w66>Wolfe 2001, p. 66.</ref> The convicted killer, [[Leo Frank]], was lynched.

On April 1, 1913, Carson performed at the first annual "Georgia Old-Time Fiddlers' Convention", held at the Municipal Auditorium in Atlanta,<ref name=r5>Russell 2007, p. 5.</ref><ref name=d18>Daniel 2001, p. 18–19.</ref> where he came in fourth.<ref name=d22>Daniel 2001, p. 22.</ref> But between 1914 and 1922, he was proclaimed "Champion Fiddler of Georgia" seven times.<ref name=r5/> The [[governor of Tennessee]], [[Robert Love Taylor|Robert L. Taylor]], dubbed him "Fiddlin' John".<ref name=w65/> In 1919, Carson began touring, mostly the areas north of Atlanta, with his newly formed band the Cronies.<ref name=mi73/><ref name=w66/> He became associated with many politicians of Georgia, like [[Thomas E. Watson|Tom Watson]], [[Herman Talmadge]], and [[Eugene Talmadge]], relations that gave rise to new songs like "Tom Watson Special".<ref name=mm17/> Carson and his daughter [[Moonshine Kate|Rosa Lee]] began a series of performances for different political campaigns: for the Tom Watson U.S. Senate Campaign in 1920, for all of the Gene Talmadge campaigns, and for the Herman Talmadge for governor campaign.<ref name=mi73/> On September 9, 1922, Carson made his radio debut at the ''[[Atlanta Journal]]'''s radio station [[WSB (AM)|WSB]] in Atlanta,<ref name=mm17/><ref name=w66/> It was reported by the ''Atlanta Journal'' that Carson's fame quickly spread all over the United States following his broadcast at WSB.<ref name=mi71>Miller 1996, p. 71.</ref>

==Career and aftermath==
[[File:The Atlanta Constitution Mon Dec 12 1949 .jpg|thumb|Carson in old age.|left]]
In early June 1923, Polk C. Brockman, an [[Atlanta]] furniture store owner, who had been instrumental in the distribution of records for [[Okeh Records]], went to New York City to work out a new business deal with Okeh Records.<ref name=w64>Wolfe 2001, p. 64.</ref><ref name=mm18>Malone, McCulloh 1975, p. 18.</ref> Later, in New York, he was asked if he knew of any artist in Atlanta that could justify a recording trip to Georgia. Brockman promised to return with an answer. A few days later, he was watching a movie followed by a silent newsreel at the Palace Theater in Times Square. The newsreel contained footage of Carson from an old time fiddler's contest in [[Virginia]]. Brockman wrote in his notebook: "Record Fiddlin' John Carson".<ref name=w65/> At his next meeting with Okeh Records Board, he persuaded [[Ralph Peer]] to go ahead and record Carson.<ref name=mi72>Miller 1996, p. 72.</ref>

On June 19, 1923,<ref>Mazor, ''Ralph Peer'', 2014, p. 53</ref> Carson made his recording debut in an empty building on Nassau Street in Atlanta, cutting two sides, "[[The Little Old Log Cabin in the Lane]]" and "The Old Hen Cackled and the Rooster's Going To Crow." Brockman told researchers in the 1960s that Peer had disliked the singing style of Carson and described it "pluperfect awful", but Peer was persuaded by Brockman to press five hundred copies for him to distribute.<ref name=mm18/><ref name=mi72/><ref name=w67>Wolfe 2001, p. 67.</ref> (Peer's biographer, Barry Mazor, argues that Peer's dissatisfaction concerned the technical quality of the recording, rather than the music, and that Peer was keen to make more recordings of Carson in New York.)<ref>Mazor, ''Ralph Peer'', 2014, pp. 54–55</ref> The recording was immediately sold out from the stage of the next Fiddler's convention on July 13, 1923.<ref name=mm18/> Peer, realizing Carson's potential, immediately invited Carson to New York City for another recording session.<ref name=mi72/> His recordings of "You Will Never Miss Your Mother Until She Is Gone" and "[[Old Joe Clark]]" both sold over one million copies.<ref name="The Book of Golden Discs">{{cite book
| first= Joseph
| last= Murrells
| year= 1978
| title= The Book of Golden Discs
| edition= 2nd
| publisher= Barrie and Jenkins Ltd
| location= London
| page= [https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/13 12/13]
| isbn= 0-214-20512-6
| url-access= registration
| url= https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/9
}}</ref>

Carson ceased recording temporarily in 1931 but resumed in 1934, now for the [[RCA Records|Victor]] label. Between 1923 and 1931, Carson recorded almost 150 songs, mostly together with the "Virginia Reelers" or his daughter Rosa Lee Carson, who performed with him as [[Moonshine Kate]].<ref name=mm18/><ref name=mm19>Malone, McCulloh 1975, p. 19.</ref> Carson's final recordings were done in Camden, New Jersey, for [[Bluebird Records]]. In 1935, Carson made a trip to Hollywood, as movie producers were eyeing him as their next big movie star. Along with Rosa Lee, he was to appear in a film called ''The Mountain Stillers'', though this never came to pass. He wrote more than 150 songs in his life, but only nine were ever copyrighted.<ref name=mi72/> Because Carson could not read sheet music, he had his songs transferred to standard notation by Irene Spain, the stepdaughter of the preacher Andrew Jenkins.<ref name=p23>Peterson 1997, p. 23</ref> Carson was involved in several copyright issues with both Okeh Records and other musicians during his active career.<ref name=mi72/>

In his later years, he worked for the local government as an elevator operator in Atlanta, a job he had obtained through his friendship with governor Herman Talmadge.<ref name=mi73/><ref name=r7>Russell 2007, p. 7.</ref> He died in 1949 in [[Atlanta]], Georgia, holding his fiddle in his arms, and is buried in Sylvester Cemetery<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.notfortourists.com/LD.aspx/Atlanta/Landmarks/Sylvester-Cemetery |title=Sylvester Cemetery – East Atlanta – Landmarks – NFT |website=Notfortourists.com |access-date=August 27, 2015 |archive-date=March 5, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305015638/http://www.notfortourists.com/ld.aspx/atlanta/landmarks/sylvester-cemetery |url-status=dead }}</ref> in the [[East Atlanta]] neighborhood of Atlanta, where surviving friends and family play music at his grave each year around the anniversary of his birth.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sylvester Cemetery|url=http://www.sylvestercemetery.org/|website=Sylvestercemetery.org|access-date=August 27, 2015}}</ref>

==Views on race and evolution==
Carson's song "There Ain't No Bugs on Me" mocked the theory of evolution, stating "there may be monkey in some of you guys, but there ain't no monkey in me". In the same song, he referenced the [[Ku Klux Klan]] ("my old man joined the Ku Klux, and ma, she lost her sheet"), whose rallies he regularly attended. Another of Carson's songs was "Ballad of Little Mary Phagan", a [[murder ballad]] that stoked the anti-Semitism present in Atlanta in the wake of [[Mary Phagan|Phagan's murder]].<ref name="cobb1999">{{Cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/redefiningsouthe0975cobb |url-access=registration |title=Redefining Southern Culture: Mind and Identity in the Modern South |last=Cobb |first=James Charles |publisher=[[University of Georgia Press]] |year=1999 |page=[https://archive.org/details/redefiningsouthe0975cobb/page/80 80] |quote=Much of the original material performed by Carson and his contemporaries consisted of folk tunes and hymns, but as recording opportunities increased, the need for new material spawned the first generation of country songwriters. Like the early recorded folk and gospel music, the first commercial compositions expressed the values and prejudices of the rural South. Fiddlin' John Carson was a regular at Ku Klux Klan rallies, and his "Ballad of Little Mary Phagan" helped to exacerbate the anti-Semitism that was a major factor in the lynching of Mary's alleged murderer, Leo Frank. Fiddlin' John made light of the evolution controversy in "There Ain't No Bugs on Me" when he asserted "there may be monkey in some of you guys, but there ain't no monkey in me," but his contemporary Vernon Dalhart took a more serious view in "The John T. Scopes Trial," concluding that "the old religion's better after all."|isbn=9780820321394 }}</ref> Carson later wrote a song in praise of the tree from which [[Leo Frank]] had been lynched.{{cn|date=August 2024}}
